title: 107_s722
content: The "Telemarketer Identification Act of 2001" prohibits interference with caller identification services. The Telemarketer Identification Act of 2001 prohibits interference with caller identification services during commercial telephone solicitations within the United States. The Telemarketer Identification Act of 2001 requires regulations for commercial telephone solicitations to include caller identification information such as the name of the person or entity making the solicitation and a valid telephone number. The Telemarketer Identification Act of 2001 mandates that commercial telephone solicitations must include caller identification information with a valid telephone number for requesting placement on a do-not-call list, which prohibits using the person's information for other telemarketing purposes. The Telemarketer Identification Act of 2001 requires commercial telephone solicitations to provide caller identification and a valid phone number for do-not-call list registration. Violations can result in legal action for monetary damages or injunctions. The Telemarketer Identification Act of 2001 allows courts to increase monetary awards up to 3 times the original amount for violations of regulations. Definitions include caller identification service and telephone call types. The Telemarketer Identification Act of 2001 allows courts to increase monetary awards for violations of regulations. Regulations prescribed by the FCC under the Communications Act of 1934 will take effect two years after the enactment of this Act, with a possible 24-month waiver for good cause shown. The Commission may grant a waiver if a person can show timely compliance with regulations is technically infeasible due to equipment issues, imposing a financial burden or being unfeasible to replace or upgrade the equipment. The Commission may grant a waiver if timely compliance with regulations is technically infeasible due to equipment issues, software unavailability, or lack of technical assistance, or if the replacement or upgrade cannot be completed before the effective date of the regulations. SEC. 3. EFFECT ON STATE LAW AND STATE ACTIONS. Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to include interfering with or circumventing caller identification services as a violation. States can take action against entities engaging in such practices.
